lines.text: KJKI EAELLIIVE
RIReynolds
Tobacco Company
Reynolds Building
4th & Main Street
Winston-Salem, NC 27102
RJRT 99-04
Contact:
Nat Walker
February 17, 1999
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. - R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company today filed suit against Zips Discount
Cigarettes, Inc., Shree Ambika, Inc., Precious Investments, Inc., and others (including as yet unnamed
distributors and retailers) who have sold "gray market" versions of Reynolds Tobacco's Winston and
Camel cigarette brands in central Florida.
The suit, which alleges trademark infringement, unfair competition, trademark dilution and unlawful
importation, was filed in federal court, in the Middle District of Florida (Tampa Division).
Gray market cigarettes are cigarettes that are intended by the manufacturer "for export only" but
instead are sold in the United States. With recent rises in cigarette prices, increasing amounts of "for
export only" cigarettes are being sold in the United States. Many of these sales are in Florida. These
gray market products have different packaging, promotional offers and blend formulations than the
corresponding brands that are manufactured for sale in the United States.
According to the complaint: "Consumers are unable or unlikely to discern that said products are
intended for export only, and that the products differ in material respects from those bearing the
Trademarks which are made for sale in the United States. Such material differences include product
content and formulations, taste profiles, promotional award programs, warranties, packaging,
distribution, handling, freshness, and post-manufacture quality control. Consumers purchasing
Defendants' said products are likely to be deceived or confused into believing that the products are
identical to those bearing the Trademarks which are made for sale in the United States."
The company contends that this deception of consumers seriously harms the value of Reynolds
Tobacco's brands sold in the United States.
Reynolds Tobacco's suit is based on violations of federal and Florida state law. The company is
seeking injunctive relief, damages and attomeys' fees from the defendants.
PRINT TIME
FEB.17.
